On this page

  • Publications

PD Benjamin Victor Ineichen

Group Leader

Email Google Scholar GitHub

He earned his MD from the University of Zurich in 2012, followed by a PhD in neuroscience from ETH Zurich in 2016. His academic journey continued with postdoctoral research fellowships at the National Institutes of Health in the USA between 2017 and 2021 and at the Karolinska Institute in Sweden from 2019 to 2020. He has also spent several years as a clinical resident in neuroradiology. In 2022, Benjamin was appointed as a “Privatdozent” (private lecturer) at the University of Zurich in the field of neuroanatomy and neuroinflammation. Since then, he has led the STRIDE-lab at the Center for Reproducible Science and the Clinical Neuroscience Center at the University of Zurich.

Benjamin’s research primarily revolves around neuroscience and neuroimaging, concentrating on multiple sclerosis from both preclinical and clinical perspectives, including systematic reviews and evidence synthesis. More recently, his work is focusing on the translation of drug development for neurological and psychiatric diseases, incorporating AI and automation in evidence synthesis, meta-science, and exploring the reproducibility of scientific research.

Beyond the lab, Benjamin finds joy in meditation and the expressive world of late romantic piano music, most interested in improvisation and composition. He is also an avid long-distance hiker, with a devotion to anything chocolate-related and a big heart for giant Teddy Bears.

Education

Ph.D. Neuroscience | University of Zurich
MD | University of Zurich
